Find the matrix $\mathbf{M}$ that triples the second row of a matrix.  In other words,
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ 3c & 3d \end{pmatrix}.\]If no such matrix $\mathbf{M}$ exists, then enter the zero matrix.
inference:
We want to find a matrix $\mathbf{M}$ such that
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ 3c & 3d \end{pmatrix}.\]

Let

$$\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} m_{11} & m_{12} \\ m_{21} & m_{22} \end{pmatrix}.$$

Then

$$\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} m_{11}a + m_{12}c & m_{11}b + m_{12}d \\ m_{21}a + m_{22}c & m_{21}b + m_{22}d \end{pmatrix}.$$

Equating this to

$$\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ 3c & 3d \end{pmatrix},$$

we get the system of equations

$$\begin{align*}
m_{11}a + m_{12}c &= a, \\
m_{11}b + m_{12}d &= b, \\
m_{21}a + m_{22}c &= 3c, \\
m_{21}b + m_{22}d &= 3d.
\end{align*}$$

Solving the first two equations for $m_{11}$ and $m_{12}$, we get

$$\begin{align*}
m_{11} &= 1, \\
m_{12} &= 0.
\end{align*}$$

Substituting these values into the third and fourth equations, we get

$$\begin{align*}
m_{21}a + m_{22}c &= 3c, \\
m_{21}b + m_{22}d &= 3d.
\end{align*}$$

Solving the first equation for $m_{21}$, we get

$$m_{21} = 2.$$

Substituting this value into the second equation, we get

$$2b + m_{22}d = 3d.$$

Solving for $m_{22}$, we get

$$m_{22} = 1.$$

Therefore, the matrix $\mathbf{M}$ that triples the second row of a matrix is

$$\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}. I hope it is correct.$

Let $\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} p & q \\ r & s \end{pmatrix}.$  Then
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} p & q \\ r & s \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} pa + qc & pb + qd \\ ra + sc & rb + sd \end{pmatrix}.\]We want this to be equal to $\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ 3c & 3d \end{pmatrix}.$  We can achieve this by taking $p = 1,$ $q = 0,$ $r = 0,$ and $s = 3,$ so $\mathbf{M} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
